author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Meryl Streep steals Oscars spotlight early
text:
Meryl Streep didn’t have to say a word to become the talk of the Academy Awards.
Up for her fourth Oscar, the legendary star earned a standing ovation from the star-studded crowd after host Jimmy Kimmel introduced her as an actress who has stood the test of time for her “many uninspiring and overrated performances.”
It was a clear jab at President Trump, who slammed Streep on Twitter as “over-rated” last month after the actress blasted the commander-in-chief’s anti-immigration stance in a memorable Golden Globes acceptance speech.
“Meryl Streep has phoned it in for over 50 films over the course of her lackluster career,” Kimmel joked, before sarcastically inviting the crowd to give her a “highly undeserved” round of applause.
It was one of many politically charged jokes Kimmel — who was hosting his first Academy Awards — unleashed at the glitzy Hollywood-based award show.
He later deadpanned that outlets like CNN and The New York Times should leave the building, days after the White House barred multiple outlets from attending Sean Spicer’s press conference.
“We have no tolerance for fake news,” he joked, adopting one of Trump’s go-to phrases to condemn the media. “Fake tans we love.”
The New York Times took out an ad during the Oscars to promote the significance of journalism and truth-telling — a move Trump bashed on Twitter as an effort by the newspaper to “save its failing reputation.”
Meryl Streep received a standing ovation at the Academy Awards. (Chris Pizzello/Chris Pizzello/Invision/AP) Diversity also took center stage early on at Sunday’s show, with “Moonlight” actor Mahershala Ali, who is African-American, winning Best Supporting Actor — the first award of the night. Viola Davis then followed by winning Best Supporting Actress for "Fences."
Their victories were significant, considering that the last two Academy Awards were overshadowed by the #OscarsSoWhite controversy after not a single nonwhite actor or actress was nominated in an acting category.
It was a far different plotline this time, with seven actors of color — including a record-setting six African-Americans — earning nominations.
Also among them were Denzel Washington of “Fences” and Ruth Negga of “Loving,” who earned highly coveted nods for Best Actor and Best Actress.
Four films featuring diverse casts — “Moonlight,” “Hidden Figures,” “Fences” and “Lion” — were among the nine movies nominated for Best Picture.
Kimmel addressed this by jokingly thanking Trump for offering some perspective.
“Remember last year when it seemed like the Oscars were racist?” he quipped.
Emma Stone's "La La Land" led all movies with 14 nominations. (Richard Shotwell/Richard Shotwell/Invision/AP) Red-hot musical “La La Land,” which has dominated awards season, missed out on the first of its record-tying 14 nominations, with the Harry Potter spinoff “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them” beating out the Los Angeles-based toe-tapper to win Best Costume Design.
“La La Land,” which swept all seven categories in which it was nominated at last month’s Golden Globes, was up for much bigger honors, however, including Best Picture.
Star Emma Stone earned a nomination for Best Actress after winning the equivalent honor at the Golden Globes and the Screen Actors Guild Awards. Among her competitors was Streep for “Florence Foster Jenkins.”
Stone’s lover in the movie, Ryan Gosling, earned a nod for Best Actor, placing him in a loaded field that also included Globes winner Casey Affleck of “Manchester by the Sea,” and Washington, who won the award at the SAGs.
Other nominations for “La La Land” included Best Original Score, Best Director and Best Song for both “City of Stars” and “Audition (The Fools Who Dream).”
Another early winner was “Suicide Squad,” which, despite poor reviews from critics and viewers alike, took home the award for makeup and hairstyling.
“O.J.: Made in America,” meanwhile, won Best Documentary.
